"But at the same time if they are going to play they have to educate themselves for this football club, not another one."
articles.teaser: KENNY DALGLISH is in no hurry to "take the nappies off" the club's crop of young talent
articles.headline: Liverpool youngsters must be patient
articles.subdeck: YOUNG GUN PLAN ... Liverpool's manager Kenny Dalglish

image.caption: SWANSEA FAN ... David Moyes

video.caption: EVERTON boss David Moyes praises on-loan Dutch star Royston Drenthe

article.caption: Latest Swansea City team news
Rodgers: Siggy deal not on table
Allen wants Sigurdsson at Liberty permanently
We've Scott to keep him
Fulham 0 Swansea 3

articles.articlebody:
EVERTON boss David Moyes has nothing but admiration for Brendan Rodgers and his Swansea "purists".

The Toffees are in Wales tomorrow to take on a Swans side who have defied expectation this season.

The Welsh team are well clear of the Premier League relegation scrap by playing an attractive brand of football.

Their progress under Rodgers has certainly impressed Moyes, who is anticipating a tough task at the Liberty Stadium, where the home team have been beaten only twice this term.

He said: "Swansea are real purists in terms of what they want to try to do.

"The style they play is great and I've admired what they have done.

"I'm looking forward to this, but it will be a tough game. We will have to make sure we try to stop the rhythm of their play, because if you don't, then they get into it.

"They are making 500 or 600 passes in every game they play  they are out-passing Manchester United and Arsenal in games.

"So you have to be aware that there will be lots of times in the game where you don't have the ball because of how well they do it."

Former Watford and Reading boss Rodgers, 39, was appointed as Swansea manager in the summer of 2010 and Moyes has paid tribute to the work done at the club in that time.

He added: "They are doing great in the league  they are certainly going to be in the Premier League next season, so it's probably just about where they finish now.

"Brendan has done a great job and has worked very hard to get into the position he is in. He deserves everything he is getting."
articles.teaser: EVERTON boss full of praise for Swansea counterpart before weekend's clash
articles.headline: Moyes hails purist Brendan
articles.subdeck: SWANSEA FAN ... David Moyes

image.caption: PLEA ... Owen Coyle hopes Fabrice Muamba's recover will inspire his Bolton troops

video.caption: OWEN COYLE reveals no Bolton players have asked to withdraw from match

article.caption: Keep Muamba in your prayers

articles.articlebody:
BOLTON boss Owen Coyle wants his players to take strength from the fighting qualities shown by Fabrice Muamba when they return to Premier League action tomorrow.

Coyle admits he does not know how his men will cope against Blackburn since Muamba suffered the cardiac arrest at Tottenham that almost claimed his life.

But the Scot does feel the stricken midfielder has shown the way by winning his personal battle despite his heart stopping for 78 minutes.

Coyle said: "If Fabrice can show what a battler is, I am sure we can play a football match.

"We are a tight-knit group of players. We are trying to build a family club here and Fabrice is a huge part of that.

"We have to be proud that we are at a fantastic club and do ourselves justice in football terms, knowing our thoughts will be with Fabrice."
articles.teaser: BOLTON manager Owen Coyle hopes Fabrice Muamba can inspire rest of his squad
articles.headline: Owen: Muamba can inspire us
articles.subdeck: PLEA ... Owen Coyle hopes Fabrice Muamba's recover will inspire his Bolton troops

image.caption: ROAD TO RECOVERY ... Fabrice Muamba

article.caption: Latest Bolton Wanderers team news
McLeish: Marvel Muamba
Power of football world has brought Fabrice back from the brink

articles.articlebody:
FABRICE MUAMBA'S family have asked for people to keep praying for the stricken midfielder.

Bolton ace Muamba remains in the London Chest Hospital after suffering a cardiac arrest during Saturday's FA Cup quarter-final with Tottenham at White Hart Lane.

While he has made significant progress, the player's father Marcel and fiancee Shauna have released a statement saying he still faces a long road ahead.

He said: "Even though Fabrice has made great progress over the last couple of days, he is still in intensive care, and still has a long period of recovery ahead.

"He has asked that you please keep him in your prayers."

It was only after talking to the pair on Tuesday that Bolton manager Owen Coyle was given the all-clear for his team to resume their Premier League campaign against Blackburn tomorrow.

Marcel and Shauna are maintaining their presence alongside Muamba and admit they have been overwhelmed by the response to the 23-year-old's plight.

The statement added: "We would like to firstly thank God for answering our prayers.

"Thank you to everyone for the love, prayers and support over the past few days.

"In particular we owe an enormous gratitude to the Bolton and Spurs medical teams for their quick reaction on Saturday, and the fantastic team here at the London Chest Hospital.

"We have been overwhelmed by all the kind messages we have received.

"The support we have had from the fans, not just from Bolton but football supporters around the world, has given us so much strength.

"We have been particularly touched by the support from the football community globally.

"Thanks also to our family and close friends and thank you to the media for respecting our privacy during this very difficult time."
articles.teaser: THE family of Fabrice Muamba have asked people to keep up the support for midfielder
articles.headline: Keep Muamba in your prayers
articles.subdeck: ROAD TO RECOVERY ... Fabrice Muamba

image.caption: EXTRA RESPONSIBILITY ... Gabriel Agbonlahor

article.caption: No strings attached
Latest Aston Villa team news
McLeish: Marvel Muamba
N'Zogbia: I'm no Villain

articles.articlebody:
ALEX McLEISH insists it would be unfair to place the goalscoring burden on Gabriel Agbonlahor.

Darren Bent's absensce with an ankle injury means Aston Villa have lost their greatest threat up front.

Ahead of this weekend's clash with Arsenal, McLeish said: "You can't keep singling out one guy in Gabby to get you the goals. We need other guys to score as well.

"We need to score from set pieces, we've not done that very well this season.

"We need goals from the wide men, we need goals from midfield.

"Stan (Stiliyan Petrov) has scored five, Charles N'Zogbia has got a couple, Gabby six or seven.

"We are looking for Gabby to get amongst the goals  but he is also a provider and his assists this season been excellent as well."

McLeish believes Agbonlahor could stake a late claim to be part of England's Euro 2012 plans if he performs well in the finale to the season.

He said: "You just want all of your players to play to their highest level in every single game and, if they do that, it is up to the powers in the England set-up to decide if they are good enough.

"But, if they keep doing it for their clubs, they've got a chance to take the next step. I would think in some capacity, England would be able to use Gabby."

McLeish enjoyed success over Arsenal in helping Birmingham to Carling Cup final glory last season.

The Scot also feels Villa should have the belief to cause another upset at the Emirates after their displays when losing 2-1 and 3-2 to the Gunners in the Premier League and FA Cup this season.

He said: "Arsenal are flying and have won six in a row, but we gave a good account of ourselves there in the FA Cup apart from collapsing a bit in a mad 15-minute spell after leading 2-0.

"We also performed well in the game at our place despite losing and won at the Emirates last season. There is no reason why the players can't believe they can win there again despite Arsenal's great form.

"It is just about having a bit of belief. No-one is unbeatable in this league."

McLeish believes Arsenal still face a battle with Tottenham to finish third despite currently having the momentum in their favour.

He said: "People say Arsenal might pip Spurs for third place but it is not finished yet. I'm sure Harry Redknapp's team will persevere to the very end.

"None of these teams give up. The Premier League is the most competitive in the world. Any team can beat any team in the league."

But McLeish knows Villa have to improve on the worst record in the Premier League this season when it comes to defending set pieces.

He said: "That record is something that rankles with the defenders.

"We conceded a lot from set pieces last season as well. It is something that has blighted the players a bit at this club over the last two seasons.

"These are things we've got to keep working on. It is disappointed we haven't halted the slide when you work at something.

"You are on the touchline looking to trust the players and then one man loses a bit of concentration and it can happen. There is definitely room for improvement in that side of things."
articles.teaser: ASTON VILLA boss insists whole team must share goals with Darren Bent out
articles.headline: Don't heap pressure on Agbonlahor
articles.subdeck: EXTRA RESPONSIBILITY ... Gabriel Agbonlahor

image.caption: BIRD LOVER ... our special pic shows how Jenson Button would look swimming with penguins

video.caption: CHRIS HOCKLEY and Jim Munro preview the second race of the new F1 season

article.caption: The Hulk's incredible guide to the Malaysian Grand Prix
F1 stars pay tribute to tragic Simoncelli
Button expects Red Bull test
From hate to great

articles.articlebody:
JENSON BUTTON has been warming up for this weekend's steaming hot Malaysian Grand Prix  by chilling out with some penguins.

Last Sunday the McLaren ace stormed his way to the chequered flag in Melbourne to win the Australian Grand Prix to get his season off to a flier.

The 32-year-old Brit star is now looking to maintain his 100 per cent start in Sepang and says he cannot wait to get behind the wheel again.

Button said: "I went swimming with penguins on Monday morning.

"I spent two days in Melbourne, relaxing and looking back on the weekend. It's funny because every couple of minutes you think 'Oh, we won. That was nice'.

"You go back to your business during the day and you just keep remembering the little things about the race and all the emotions you went through.

"On Monday night I had a couple of drinks with some friends which was really nice. It all helps to get you ready for the next one.

"You're already looking forward to it and you're on the phone to the engineer and he's all excited as well.

"We look back at last weekend and it was great  but we know there are another 19 of those that we want to win."

Button is still on a high after his brilliant drive around Albert Park where he leapfrogged team-mate Lewis Hamilton at the start.

Hamilton, who had to settle for third behind the Red Bull of world champ Sebastian Vettel, has promised not to beat himself up after slipping two places from qualifying.

The 27-year-old jetted straight to Kuala Lumpur to prepare for this Sunday's race but, instead of enjoying the anticipated scorching weather, he was forced to stay in his hotel due to the downpours outside.

When quizzed how he spent the start to this week, he added: "Jenson went swimming with some penguins? That sounds great.

"I just chilled, watched movies and did some training. I watched Back to the Future and a few other different movies. It was raining quite a lot where we were."

Hamilton is now ready to make amends for last weekend's disappointment and will be gunning for victory come Sunday.

He said: "If you start 10th and you finish second or third it is a great weekend.

"But if you start first you are never going to be happy with anything less than first.

"I have looked into the last race as much as I needed to. There were a few things that didn't go my way and were out of my control. There was nothing I could do about it.

"In the race this weekend hopefully those things won't get in the way and I will have a better weekend."
articles.byline: From BEN HUNT in Kuala Lumpur
articles.teaser: MCLAREN star warms up for steaming hot Malaysian GP  by chilling out with penguins
articles.headline: Button chills before heat of Sepang
articles.subdeck: BIRD LOVER ... our special pic shows how Jenson Button would look swimming with penguins

articles.articlebody:
KIMI RAIKKONEN has been hit with a five-place grid penalty for Sunday's Malaysian Grand Prix.

The Lotus driver faces the automatic demotion after his mechanics couldn't repair the troublesome gearbox that ended his involvement on last weekend's opening Grand Prix of 2012 in Melbourne.

Under FIA rules for F1, a driver must use one gearbox for five successive races and any unscheduled change will cost the driver five places on the grid.

The team's official twitter account revealed: "A bit more work for Kimi's crew this evening. An issue with Kimi's gearbox so we're changing it now."

A Lotus spokeswoman later confirmed that the penalty would come into force.

articles.headline: Kimi stuck in the wrong gear

image.caption: LEGEND ... Lance Storm

articles.articlebody:
FORMER WCW and WWF star Lance Storm expects the WWE title match at Wrestlemania to be 'spectacular'.

Canadian hero Storm broke into the business with Chris Jericho over twenty years ago after they both trained at the Hart Brothers wrestling school in Calgary.

The pair went on to form a team called The Thrillseekers and perform all over the world.

Storm, now semi-retired, runs a training school called Storm Wrestling Academy in Calgary and was visited by Jericho before he returned to WWE in January.

Jericho will challenge CM Punk for the WWE championship at Mania on April 1 and Storm reckons the match has all the makings of a possible classic encounter.

Speaking exclusively to SunSport, the 42-year-old said: "I think Jericho and Punk are really going to knock people's socks off.

"When Chris came up to Calgary to chip off the ring rust before his latest return, he knew at that point where it was going and he and I pitched ideas and threw stuff back and forth.

"There's a good chance that there will be spots that will end up being in the match that I actually did with him in Calgary several months ago. It's well laid groundwork.

"The fact that he has had this seed planted in his mind for several months, I'm expecting it to be quite spectacular.

"He is someone who has a full grasp on the industry and is putting out when he feels is the best build and the best product. Not 'what can I best do for me'.

"He really is a consummate pro and really knows the ins and outs of what makes a great match.

"He's really, really spectacular and I expect this to be really standout."

Busy with his training school and content not to undertake the gruelling travel schedule top wrestlers have to endure, Storm is happy to only occasionally strap on his wrestling boots.

On Wrestlemania weekend, though, in Florida, he will be making a rare wrestling appearance in taking on Mike Bennett for top Indy promotion Ring of Honor.

Bennett is the real-life boyfriend of stunning former WWE diva Maria Kanellis, who also accompanies her man for his matches in ROH.

The match will take place at ROH's Showdown in the Sun iPPV, and Lance says that he is only accepting the bout because he rates Bennett highly.

Storm said: "I'm very choosy about who I work with now. Since I wrapped up the full-time career I only work with people I'm interested in working with.

"He's got a ton of talent. I think he stands out a little more in Ring of Honor in that he tends to work his own style and be a bit different than the other Ring of Honor guys.

"Having Maria there is an interesting twist too, in that I was the first person who started training her when she got hired by WWE. It should be a lot of fun.

"I'm not coming back to have a match that just blends into the card and doesn't stand out.

"I plan on really putting in a huge effort and having a standout performance on that show despite how great the rest of the card is going to be."

After calling time on his full-time in-ring career in 2004, Storm worked for OVW  WWE's former developmental territory in Ohio  where he helped to train several wrestlers who now adorn our screens on a weekly basis.

One of the standouts of the group Storm tutored in OVW was Dolph Ziggler, who many have compared to legends such as Shawn Michaels and Curt Hennig and have tipped for the top in the future.

Storm agrees that Ziggler could be a major star someday, but warns he must be careful not to damage himself along the way.

He added: "Dolph was a quick learner right out of the gate. I pretty much had him from scratch.

"I worked with him for almost a year in OVW and it wasn't too long after that he made his debut with the Spirit Squad.

"You can just imagine how nervous he must have been with only about a year of training behind him and not a whole lot of experience.

"He was in the ring with Triple H and Shawn Michaels doing a feud with DX.

"I keep having to remind him to be careful, because when you are throwing around names like Shawn Michaels and Curt Hennig, you also have to remember that both of them had very bad backs that hampered their career.

"I keep reminding him that while it's great to take amazing bumps, you don't have to do so on every single move."

For more information about ROH Showdown in the Sun, including Storm v Bennett, go to https://www.rohwrestling.com/

To listen to the full 50-minute interview, check out Rob McNichol's One Sided Ring podcast.
articles.teaser: LANCE STORM predicts big things from Chris Jericho and CM Punk at Mania
articles.headline: Storm: Wrestlemania title bout will be 'spectacular'
articles.subdeck: LEGEND ... Lance Storm

image.caption: BO NO! ... Ravi injury is causing England a headache

article.caption: Prior smashes England to strong win
Amir must focus on rehabilitation

articles.articlebody:
ENGLAND'S plans were thrown into further confusion yesterday when Ravi Bopara was told he cannot bowl in the Test series.

With Ian Bell desperately short of runs and Stuart Broad still feeling his ankle, this was the last thing England needed.

Bopara can play only as a specialist batsman after straining his side bowling in the final practice match.

It is a major blow to the intended balance of the team as they wanted the Essex man to send down a few overs of medium-pacers in the Tests.

The pressure will be on the four main bowlers  James Anderson, Graeme Swann, Broad and Monty Panesar  to do virtually all the work in the ferocious heat.

It would be disastrous if one of those is ruled out.

England do have Bell and Jonathan Trott, who both bowled yesterday, plus Kevin Pietersen to fill in with a few extra overs.

But none is as good as Bopara. Despite not being able to bowl, he is likely to keep his place at No 6 after hitting 66 in the four-wicket win over a Sri Lankan Development XI.

England could leave out Bopara and play another bowler in the First Test on Monday  but Andrew Strauss and Andy Flower have never adopted that strategy.

Keeper Matt Prior, who scored 84 from 60 balls yesterday, said: "With the heat out here, that role of bowling a few is vital. It means the main bowlers can have a bit of a break.

"If we do decide to go with five bowlers and I'm asked to bat one place higher than normal at No 6, I'll be happy to grab that chance."

Bell was out for 11 and he now has 136 runs in 15 innings since the end of last summer. But fifties by Bopara, Pietersen, Prior and Samit Patel hustled England over the line after they were set 359 in 64 overs.

Prior added: "Bell is hitting it fantastically in the nets, so I wouldn't be surprised if he comes out and smashes a hundred in the first Test.

"We see batsmen struggling time and time again. Alastair Cook wasn't meant to go the Ashes 18 months ago  and look what happened."

  • Sri Lanka have dismissed reports that ex-skipper Tillakeratne Dilshan had an affair with Bollywood actress Nupur Mehta, who has been linked to 'honeytrap' stings that lure players into match fixing.
articles.teaser: BOPARA has been told he can't bowl in the Test series in Sri Lanka, starting next week
articles.headline: Ravi injury rocks England plans
articles.subdeck: BO NO! ... Ravi injury is causing England a headache

article.caption: Tulisa is dragged into sex vid storm
X Factor Tulisa is so Skin love
Tulisa Contostavlos beds TOWIE hunk Mark Wright

articles.articlebody:
SIMON Cowell last night stood by Tulisa Contostavlos over her sex tape scandal  and said she would remain an X Factor judge.

The TV guru spoke out after 23-year-old N-Dubz star Tulisa admitted she WAS the girl in a smutty video that was touted online.

Furious Simon blasted the "scumbag" who leaked the erotic video.

The telly mogul declared the row would have no impact on the star's talent show job and revealed he hit the roof after hearing the home-made film was for sale on the net.

He said the person who leaked it had "sold what was something private"  and insisted: "What she was doing was not illegal.

"You are allowed to do this stuff in your bedroom, but you don't want the tape to come out."

Simon, 52, also said he had not seen the film  but joked: "I am going to watch it tonight."

Turning to the person behind the online leak, he added: "Whoever he is, he's a scumbag  and I'm being really conservative with my words here.

"It's disgusting, repulsive. He's embarrassed her and he's got no right to put her in this position.

"He should literally find a hole and hide in it for the next week. It really, really annoys me. It's like, 'Who do you think you are?'"

Stressing his support for N-Dubz singer Tulisa, Simon went on: "It makes no difference with me about her coming back on the show  100 per cent.

"I mean, God, if I said no (to her coming back) it's allowing every sleazebag in the country to wreck somebody's career when she didn't do something wrong.

"The public are very, very a) forgiving, and b) understanding. But I hope they don't forgive the person who did it."

Simon said all four of last year's X Factor judges  Tulisa, Gary Barlow, Louis Walsh and Kelly Rowland  were set to return. The Sun has already revealed that Gary will be back.

Despite Simon's backing, the leaked video scandal showed no signs of easing up last night.

The man Tulisa says appears in the video  Justin Edwards  has made a series of claims about the origin of the six-minute film.

The Sun can reveal that he told the X Factor judge's lawyers last October that he didn't have a copy of it.

Tulisa, who is said to be "completely devastated" by the leak, set the law firm on Edwards  known as MC Ultra  after apparently learning about the online leaks.

In response, he stated that he had "no knowledge whatsoever of any tape" and didn't have "a tape such as you referred to at all".

He added in his response to the lawyers: "Even if I did which I do not, I would have no desire to publish them, simply because I would find that ungentlemanly. I was brought up better than that."

Rapper Edwards made the denial just weeks after an unknown man showed The Sun images of a woman performing a sex act. He claimed the woman was Tulisa.

Yesterday, after Tulisa claimed in a YouTube video that HE had leaked the camera-phone footage, Edwards said on Twitter: "To find the truth both sides of the story should be heard."

Tulisa had initially denied she was in the video. But after a website this week started charging for downloads, her lawyers raced to London's High Court to have it taken offline.

And on Wednesday night Tulisa admitted she WAS the woman in the film.

The singer  poised to launch a solo career  said on YouTube: "When you share an intimate moment with someone you love, you never imagine that at any point it will be shared with people around the world.

"It's a pretty tough time for me, but I don't feel I should take the heat for it."

c.robertson@the-sun.co.uk
articles.byline: By COLIN ROBERTSON, TV Editor, and GARY O’SHEA
articles.teaser: MUSIC guru Simon Cowell stands by Tulisa Contostavlos over her sex tape scandal
articles.headline: Cowell: Sex tape Tulisa hasn't blown her job

articles.articlebody:
WHITNEY Houston's death was triggered by cocaine, a coroner's report revealed last night.

An autopsy on the singer, 48, found the cause of death was drowning due to heart disease and cocaine use.

The Los Angeles coroner revealed the superstar singer, 48, took a line "immediately" before she drowned in a Beverly Hills hotel bathtub last month.

Toxicology results indicated "chronic use" of cocaine over time had contributed to the heart disease. It is believed the Bodyguard star suffered a heart attack before slipping under the water and drowning.

Relatives were said to be devastated at hearing cocaine was to blame.

Whitney's family said in a statement: "We are saddened to learn of the toxicology results, although we are glad to now have closure."

Her mum Cissy, 79, and daughter Bobbi Kristina, 19, have been struggling to cope since the tragedy.

Coroner's spokesman Craig Harvey confirmed Whitney appeared to have used cocaine "in the time period immediately prior to her collapse in the bathtub".

A report from the coroner's office stated: "How injury occurred: Found submerged in a bathtub filled with water; cocaine intake."

It said Whitney also had marijuana, Benadryl, Xanax and other medication in her system, but those drugs were NOT a factor.

Investigators had said they found no evidence of illegal drugs at the scene, although officials confirmed prescription pill bottles were found.

American showbiz site TMZ reported sources that claimed a mystery individual removed any traces of cocaine from Whitney's hotel room.

They also alleged that the person who cleaned up the drugs had supplied them to the singer.

It added that Beverly Hills Police have confirmed their investigation into Whitney's death had not yet been finished.

But the site said cops would not comment on whether they were looking at any allegations of evidence tampering

The coroner's report said her death was an accident, and added: "No trauma or foul play is suspected."

The coroner's office said results indicated Whitney also suffered from heart disease that caused 60 per cent narrowing of her arteries.

Assistant Chief Coroner Ed Winter said the condition is common in cocaine users.

He said: "It just beats up their heart and they will have a heart attack."

A final, more detailed, coroner's report will be released in two weeks.

Whitney battled addiction to crack cocaine at the height of her fame. Some blamed her stormy 14-year marriage to Bobby Brown.

p.samson@the-sun.co.uk
articles.teaser: STAR died of accidental drowning due to the effects of cocaine use and heart disease, coroner says
articles.headline: Coroner: Cocaine killed Whitney
articles.subdeck: Tragic ... Whitney Houston on night out just two days before her death

article.caption: Rihanna is a Good Girl Gone Bad geisha
RiRi parties with her grandparents
Rih-united with Chris Brown because he's 'the hottest star in R&B'
Drake's action Rihplay
Rihanna stars in her own 'Where's Wally?' cartoon on a night out in NYC

articles.articlebody:
WHAT could a single pop star be doing at a newly single actor's house between midnight and 4am?

Playing Scrabble? Go For Broke? Monopoly? Charades?

Rihanna paid a late-night visit to Ashton Kutcher at his LA mansion in the small hours of yesterday morning.

The singer was snapped knocking on the Two And A Half Men star's door at 12am in a pair of denim hotpants.

She then popped in and stayed for four hours. She must have forgotten her toothbrush.

Earlier she had a quiet meal with a female pal at Giorgio Baldi's restaurant in Santa Monica. Whatever Rihanna was drinking put her in the mood for male company, so she headed to see Demi Moore's ex.

A source said: "It has been a while since Ashton was getting late-night visits from pretty girls.

"He has been on his best behaviour, but when Demi finds out, you can only imagine what she'll think. She is old enough to be Rihanna's mum."

Ashton's marriage fell apart because of his wandering eye.

But in all fairness to him, he might just have been offering some acting tips. Rihanna is in the process of buying the rights to a Whitney Houston biopic.

She has been in touch with Whitney's daughter Bobbi Kristina for her blessing. A source said: "Rihanna has spoken to Bobbi about the project.

"She's desperate to pick up the rights and thinks she could play her part in a great Hollywood tribute to her mum."

Jennifer Hudson and Beyonce have also been linked with future Whitney films.

Going back to Rihanna's four hours at Ashton's...

By my calculations that's just enough time to get a big spider out of the bath and give a recently single man some counselling for his ordeal.
articles.teaser: RIHANNA spotted leaving Ashton Kutcher's apartment at 4am
articles.headline: Rihanna spotted leaving Ashton Kutcher's apartment at 4am

image.caption: Out soon ... Madonna's new album MDNA

article.caption: Madonna: I like to work with people who talk about philosophy or quantum physics

articles.articlebody:
MADONNA is back  bigger, brighter and bolder then ever  with her electrifying new album MDNA.

And you can listen for FREE with The Sun below.

The album will be released Monday, March 26 on Interscope, so this is your chance to hear it here first.

The Queen of Pop reclaims her crown with this her 12th studio album to date; a collection of shiny, dancefloor anthems set to take the roof off summer.

Co-written by Madonna, album highlights include the glorious William Orbit-produced I'm A Sinner, which recalls the heyday of Ray of Light, and Falling Free, a beautiful, soaring ballad.

There's a pounding clubland stomper in Turn Up The Radio, produced by French electronic DJ and producer Martin Solveig.

Then there's the poptastic punch of Superstar, featuring Madonna's daughter Lourdes on backing vocals, I Don't Give A featuring Nicki Minaj and first single Give Me All Your Luvin, feat. Nicki Minaj & M.I.A., which were both produced by Martin Solveig.

Renowned Italian electro house DJ and producer Marco "Benny" Benassi adds an extra sheen to salacious rave-ups I'm Addicted and Girl Gone Wild.
articles.teaser: EXCLUSIVE: FIRST stream of Queen of Pop's electrifying new album MDNA
articles.headline: First listen of Madonna album
articles.subdeck: Out soon ... Madonna's new album MDNA

THE WANTED are really living the dream  playing here to dozens of bikini babes at an MTV Spring Break pool party.

Singer Jay McGuiness even got a kiss off one fan at the Las Vegas gig.

The Brit boyband later partied at one of Playboy boss Hugh Hefner's hotel suites in the city  where Jay and fellow singleton Nathan Sykes enjoyed a dip with naked Playmates.

A source said: "Nathan ended up in there with two naked girls  and Jay didn't do too badly either."

Bandmates Max George, Tom Parker and Siva Kaneswaran and relaxed over drinks and got their fair share of attention too.

The only damage Brit rivals One Direction have managed Stateside is breaking some bowling equipment.

IT didn't take Kate Moss long to christen her £8million gaff.

The supermodel moved into her new home in Highgate, north London on Wednesday and by the evening she and her pals were tearing up the place.

The mansion has four storeys and a wine cellar  which already needs to be restocked.

ROBBIE WILLIAMS has finally packed in his last vice  smoking.

The Take That singer has been puffing 40 fags a day for years but is now having a serious crack at giving up.

EMOTIONAL Jack Tweed lays flowers at wife Jade Goody's grave yesterday to mark the third anniversary of her death.

The 24-year-old had tears in his eyes as he crouched by the Big Brother legend's memorial in Upshire, Essex, and read cards left by well-wishers.

Jack  who wed mum-of-two Jade, 27 right, weeks before she died of cervical cancer in 2009  said online: "Three years ago today Heaven gained an angel. Gone but never forgotten."

image.caption: Simon Cowell ... 'Silly rivalry'

article.caption: David Walliams: Fans always ask me if Simon likes men or laydees
Cheryl Cole Voices single in Simon Cowell snub
Judge and fury
A Hol' lot of love

articles.articlebody:
SIMON COWELL has blasted new talent show The Voice, accusing BBC bosses of "silly rivalry".

The Britain's Got Talent chief reckons the Beeb have splurged £22million of licence payers' money on the US import only because they hate how successful his singing contest The X Factor is.

Simon has warned he is armed if they want to do battle as BGT and The Voice go head-to-head in the ratings tomorrow evening  overlapping by 20 minutes.

Initial schedules showed the clash of times between the shows would have been 50 minutes  but ITV moved BGT 30 minutes backwards so their millions of fans wouldn't have to choose.

Raging Simon said: "Am I going to watch The Voice? I'll probably watch about five minutes of it, not the whole thing.

"When you get to the point with your shows where you mess around with schedules and it affects the viewers when you go head-to-head that's silly rivalry.

"They're winding this up like it's a battle. It's down to being good, being successful. Of course you need competition but ask the BBC if we need another singing talent show. I would query whether we do or not.

"They don't like the fact that X Factor is successful, they have every right to compete and we have the right to arm ourselves so we're in a good place to beat them."

And new BGT judge David Walliams piped up against the BBC's claims they are the only show interested in finding "real talent".

David said: "Susan Boyle has sold 25 to 30million albums, that speaks for itself."

Simon, with usual bluntness, accused the BBC of having lost their sense of humour.

But he admitted to poaching Alesha Dixon from Strictly Come Dancing to join him, Amanda Holden and David Walliams on the BGT panel  to spite BBC executives.

He said: "Once we decided we wanted four people on the panel, I thought I'd love Alesha to join. There is so much rivalry with Strictly and X Factor  they're always messing around with the schedule and The Voice was 100 per cent intended as a competing show to X Factor.

"So I thought, 'You know what, let's have some fun.' "

At yesterday's launch Amanda Holden rubbished criticism she went back to work too early after having baby Hollie.

She said: "Digging the road is work, sitting at a desk pressing a buzzer is a treat."
articles.teaser: MUSIC mogul blasts new show The Voice, accusing BBC bosses of 'silly rivalry'
articles.headline: 'Voice rivalry is waste of telly fee'
articles.subdeck: Simon Cowell ... 'Silly rivalry'

image.caption: So in love ... star Gregg Wallace with Heidi

article.caption: 'MasterChef viewers wait for rude remarks but that stuff just comes out'
Food for thought for MasterChef's final three
New cookery rival to Beeb's Saturday Kitchen

articles.articlebody:
HEARTBROKEN Masterchef star Gregg Wallace says he is still in love with third wife Heidi despite their marriage falling apart.

Gregg, 47, spoke to diners at his plush West London restaurant, telling them: "I'm absolutely devastated."

Heidi, 30, revealed on Twitter that the pair had split  three years after they first met through the message site.

Nursing a half-empty bottle of red wine, Gregg told customers at his eaterie Wallace & Co in Putney: "I've had a terrible week. I'm in bits.

"I love my wife  I don't know what's gone wrong. She announced it on Twitter. Heidi is an amazing woman. She's brilliant."

He said he is still close to Heidi, who also acts as his PA. He added: "We still talk to each other three or four times a day."

Dressed in jeans and white trainers, the former greengrocer turned TV presenter said their marriage reached breaking point around Christmas time.

He said: "It's all gone mad. It went wrong about three months ago. We knew there was something wrong. We want different things.

"We both have images of each other  I don't know if they were right. I'm an awkward b****r. I'm demanding."

Gregg also blamed the fact he spent so much time working in London while Heidi stayed at their home in Whitstable, Kent.

He said: "I like working and making money. I'm always thinking about what I'm going to do next. I'm driven."

The chef, who has just opened a new restaurant Gregg's Table in Bermondsey, South London, told diners: "I'm here all the time. I live here. Heidi lives in Whitstable.

"I'm always busy, always trying to build the business, do the TV."

Gregg  who rose to fame alongside chef John Torode as a judge on BBC1's Masterchef  married Heidi 14 months ago.

They got together in 2009 after Heidi sent him a flirty message on Twitter, and moved in together just four months later.

Gregg  who was a single dad of two when they met  says Heidi has vowed to continue being involved with his son Tom, 18, and daughter Libby, 15.

He said: "She's been absolutely brilliant with my kids.

"My son has just done amazing in his exams and that's all down to Heidi. She loves my kids to death.

"She says she's prepared to look after them however long it takes, and I'm happy for them to stay with her. She's devoted to them."

He denied the 17-year age gap was to blame for their split, insisting: "We always joke that she's more mature than me  she says she's an old woman in a young woman's body.

"She's never been interested in fame. She didn't like coming to red carpet events. People thought she was interested in me because I'm famous, but nothing's further from the truth.

"She says she'll always be there for me. She wants to continue as my PA. She says she'll work for me for the next 30 years."

Heidi wrote on Twitter at the weekend: "I can confirm that Gregg and I have separated. All amicable and still very close. He's a wonderful man."

Gregg has been bombarded with tweets from admirers  including one woman begging: "Marry me!"

But he said: "I'm not interested in other women. Have you seen pictures of my wife? She's absolutely stunning."

article.caption: Andy Whyment: DOI's given me a boy's body
Noel on X Factor 'for £1m'
Matt Wolfenden is made up for Rock Week
Paul Weller in a Jam as outed fan of X Factor
Noel Gallagher: I'd be great on X Factor

articles.articlebody:
ROCK star Noel Gallagher has revealed he struggled with fatherhood and family  until second wife Sara MacDonald taught him how real families work.

The ex Oasis star, whose dad left mum Peggy to bring up him and brothers Liam and Paul, admits he didn't know how to parent.

Speaking in BBC4's Mark Lawson Talks To Noel Gallagher, the dad of three said: "I had never seen a good example of any parenting until I met Sara, who is an incredible mother to the children."

Noel has two sons with Sara  Donovan, four, and Sonny, 17 months  and daughter Anais, 12, with first wife Meg Mathews.

He added: "I have learnt so much from her as she has great parents. Her mum and dad have been married for 150 years or something and they are still together. And she takes that and brings that to our children.

"I come from a dysfunctional family. I'm good with the kids now but at first, with my older daughter, I didn't have the tools instinctively." He also talked about his mother Peggy and estranged father Thomas  who separated when Noel was 15  and his spats with younger brother Liam.

Of Peggy he said: "We were three lads and it was tricky for her bringing us up on our own.

"She gave it all up for us. I think she has great karma and two of her children became two of the biggest rock stars that England ever produced.

"All she got was a new garden gate from us. Liam offered to buy her a castle in Alderley Edge but the gate at her council house had been squeaking and she wanted that fixed.

"She still lives there and we changed it and put a gold number 5 on the gate.

"I don't think of my father at all. It's his loss, not mine."

Oasis notched up eight UK number one albums and eight chart-topping singles, the first Some Might Say in 1995. But Noel and Liam fell out in 2009 and the band split.

And Noel said of Liam: "There is no contact of any significance, to my mother's disgust. But we are big boys now. She can't tell us what to do for ever.

"It's not the last time I'm ever going to speak to him. Of course I'm going to speak to him again but I'm busy."

Watch the full interview on BBC4 at 11.20pm on March 30.
articles.teaser: ROCKER struggled with fatherhood until his 2nd wife taught him how families work
articles.headline: Gallagher: Wife taught me to be a dad
articles.subdeck: Noel Gallagher ... 'Sarah is an incredible mother to the children'

Simon Cowell style shocker

articles.articlebody:
ALESHA DIXON was on cloud nine yesterday  as she rocked a sky-print dress for the launch of Britain's Got Talent.

But the jury is out on whether the frock by Vivetta was a fashion success.

The telly judge teamed the brave fashion choice  which featured cut-out panels, optical illusions and a little white tie  with black buckled boots.

And the OTT capped shoulders could put her in good stead for a stint on an American football pitch if things don't work out for her on BGT.

Earlier this year the singer was wooed away from BBC programme Strictly Come Dancing to join the ITV1 rival show by boss Simon Cowell.

The move has seen Alesha's paypacket boosted from around £100,000 to £350,000  but Alesha denies she was swayed by the cash.

She said: "I don't miss Strictly, I had an incredible time on Strictly but it's a different vibe on this show. It is a whole lot of fun.

"It's certainly not about the money, it's about doing different things.

"I honestly don't make decisions based on money  that is the truth.

"I just think that, for me, it has been time for a change and for me it has been a great change."

Tomorrow night Britain's Got Talent goes head to head with the new BBC1 singing competition The Voice.

She'll be hoping that BGT storms ahead in the ratings war  as defeat would definitely rain on her parade.

image.caption: Intelligent conversation ... Madonna

article.caption: Be the first to hear Madonna's new album
Madonna has a buff time in her new video
Madonna rolls back the years on new album

articles.articlebody:
CALLING Madonna and interrupting her son's French lesson sounds like a recipe for an uncomfortable half an hour on the phone.

A mum of four's time is precious, especially when she has an album to finish and a gruelling tour to play for.

But the Queen of Pop couldn't have been more enthusiastic and open about her 12th studio album MDNA  which might have something to do with the great reviews it has already received.

It's out on Monday but you can hear it first and free here.

In October of this year Madonna will celebrate the 30th anniversary of the release of her first single Everybody.

Since then she has toured the world nine times, won countless awards and scored ten No1 solo albums.

But the singer, 53, still finds the presentation of new material a nerve-racking experience.

Speaking exclusively to SFTW, she said: "I don't think presenting any of my work is less nerve-racking than it ever was because I put my heart and soul into something.

"Whether it's on a film or my record, it's something to work on in privacy and create in a kind of bubble and then put it out in the world.

"You never know how people are going to receive it, whether it's going to move them or inspire them. The world is so full of entertainment now, isn't it? So there are a lot of nerves.

"It's amazing to be back in music. I like the intimacy of a recording studio and song-writing. I'm using a different part of my brain when I work on music versus when I'm directing a film.

"There are a billion more people on a film and I don't have that visceral outlet of being able to sing, scream... jump around.

"It's very different. I love doing both but it was nice to have the simplicity of song-writing after three years of writing a script and directing and editing and talking about my film, to sit down and play my guitar and sing a song. I almost cried."

Her last studio album, Hard Candy in May 2008, experimented with a hip-hop influence. She collaborated with Justin Timberlake, Pharrell Williams and Timbaland.

The album reached No1 around the world but received a lukewarm reception from some fans and critics.

MDNA, a "triple entendre" as she describes it, is a return to what she does best: classic pop songs with a sprinkling of trademark controversy.

And it is down to the return of her winning formula: working with top European producers.

Stuart Price produced some of her best original material on Confessions On A Dancefloor back in 2005. She also made some great material with French electronic guru Mirwais.

But her return to the studio with producer William Orbit, who made Ray Of Light back in 1998, is a master stroke.

The tracks they have made together on the new album, including Gang Bang and Some Girls, slot into her discography perfectly.

She has also employed the skills of Martin Solveig, Italian DJ Benny Benassi and his cousin Allessandro.

And Madonna believes her return to Europe for her producing partners is no coincidence.

She explained: "I think maybe I just have more of a European sensibility. People say that about my songs as well. I like working with people who are well-read and know what's going on in the world.

"Conversation is essential. With William, we always get into discussions about philosophy or quantum physics.

"With Martin Solveig we always end up getting in to discussions about foreign films. When I'm working with people I can't just write music, I have to be able to talk about life and the world, and art. Benny was a tricky one because he doesn't speak English very well.

"I ended up kind of using his cousin Allessandro as an interpreter.

"It was a little bit frustrating at first but eventually we found a way to communicate. You figure out a way. With music it's so much about the vibe and the energy and you know when things are working and when they're not.

"When you're working with someone for the first time, there's a kind of shyness that everybody has, so with Benny it was more challenging because of that but we figured it out and by the end I felt like I knew him very well.

"Martin is such good fun, I adore him. You have to feel like you can say 'No, I don't like that,' and you're not going to hurt their feelings. And vice versa.

"But he's got just the right balance of seriousness and humour.

"He's very organised and methodical in his thinking so I like his work process."

The production on the album is slick, with some great touches.

On Gang Bang the noise of a spent cartridge from a gun hitting a concrete floor illustrates her "Kill Bill" fantasy for the track.

But the contrast of a huge pop track like Superstar, featuring her daughter Lourdes on backing vocals, is followed up with a song called Falling Free  one of her most stripped-back songs for years. She explained: "I have to be completely involved in the production. I like the contrast.

"I like to have something that is just slammed with noise and sound and bass and drum, sensory overload and then create something like Falling Free, which is stripped back and all you can really hear is my voice and the lyrics.

"Sometimes I sit down on a guitar and start strumming chords and things come out.

"Sometimes people bring a song to me that has a title, for instance, or an idea of a lyric and I take it and kind of re-shape it, re-word it and make it my own. It comes in so many different ways, it's always been that way."

The album features some big collaborations with strong female solo stars  M.I.A and rapper Nicki Minaj. Give Me All Your Luvin' was the Superbowl song that ended up causing controversy when M.I.A decided to stick up her middle fin ger.

But that punk spirit is exactly why she got them on board.

She said: "I was looking to collaborate with women who I think have a strong sense of themselves.

"They were a lot of fun to be around in the studio, for sure.

"I think we were all shy of each other in the beginning, that's just human nature.

"I think we got over that pretty quickly.

"They're both very self-possessed people, especially M.I.A. I don't think she's impressed much by stars and celebrities, so we just got down to business. I loved her."

And the key to keeping the music original? Don't listen to chart music while you are writing.

She said: "I wasn't listening to anything to tell you the truth, when I wrote this.

"I was working on the soundtrack to my movie W.E. So just classical music. I actually don't like listening to pop music while I'm working on pop music  it doesn't really work.

"You don't want to hear other people's stuff, you need a clean slate to work off."
articles.teaser: TIME is precious for the mum of four  she has an album and tour to finish
articles.headline: Madonna: I like to work with people who talk about philosophy or quantum physics
articles.subdeck: Intelligent conversation ... Madonna

article.caption: Carter the unstoppable pecs machine
Plait's a great look, Helen

articles.articlebody:
DISNEY sci-fi epic John Carter is set to lose £126million this financial quarter  making it the biggest movie flop of all time.

It cost £158million to make the film about a 19th-century US Civil War soldier transported to Mars.

Disney also spent £63million promoting it. But ticket sales  shared with cinemas  only total £116million.

Studio chairman Rich Ross said: "It failed to connect with audiences."

Based on a book by Tarzan creator Edgar Rice Burroughs, the film stars Taylor Kitsch.

The singer will be in Hands Of Stone, the story of fighter Roberto Duran  played by Gael Garcia Bernal.

Usher said: "I'm in preparation for an incredible role. If you guys see me running around London, that's what it is.

video.caption: CORONER says singer accidentally drowned after using cocaine

article.caption: Whitney Houston 'planned to remarry Bobby Brown'
Bobbi: I still talk to mum
Whitney Houston 'died of drug and booze cocktail'
Whitney Houston buried... Bobby Brown hits casino
'Whitney family fears Brown is after her millions'
First image of bath tub where Whitney died

articles.articlebody:
WHITNEY Houston's death was triggered by cocaine, a coroner's report revealed last night.

An autopsy on the singer, 48, found the cause of death was drowning due to heart disease and cocaine use.

The Los Angeles coroner revealed the superstar singer, 48, took a line "immediately" before she drowned in a Beverly Hills hotel bathtub last month.

Toxicology results indicated "chronic use" of cocaine over time had contributed to the heart disease. It is believed the Bodyguard star suffered a heart attack before slipping under the water and drowning.

Relatives were said to be devastated at hearing cocaine was to blame.

Whitney's family said in a statement: "We are saddened to learn of the toxicology results, although we are glad to now have closure."

Her mum Cissy, 79, and daughter Bobbi Kristina, 19, have been struggling to cope since the tragedy.

Coroner's spokesman Craig Harvey confirmed Whitney appeared to have used cocaine "in the time period immediately prior to her collapse in the bathtub".

A report from the coroner's office stated: "How injury occurred: Found submerged in a bathtub filled with water; cocaine intake."

It said Whitney also had marijuana, Benadryl, Xanax and other medication in her system, but those drugs were NOT a factor.

Investigators had said they found no evidence of illegal drugs at the scene, although officials confirmed prescription pill bottles were found.

American showbiz site TMZ reported sources that claimed a mystery individual removed any traces of cocaine from Whitney's hotel room.

They also alleged that the person who cleaned up the drugs had supplied them to the singer.

It added that Beverly Hills Police have confirmed their investigation into Whitney's death had not yet been finished.

But the site said cops would not comment on whether they were looking at any allegations of evidence tampering

The coroner's report said her death was an accident, and added: "No trauma or foul play is suspected."

The coroner's office said results indicated Whitney also suffered from heart disease that caused 60 per cent narrowing of her arteries.

Assistant Chief Coroner Ed Winter said the condition is common in cocaine users.

He said: "It just beats up their heart and they will have a heart attack."

A final, more detailed, coroner's report will be released in two weeks.

Whitney battled addiction to crack cocaine at the height of her fame. Some blamed her stormy 14-year marriage to Bobby Brown.

p.samson@the-sun.co.uk
articles.teaser: STAR died of accidental drowning due to the effects of cocaine use and heart disease, coroner says
articles.headline: Coroner: Cocaine killed Whitney

image.caption: 'I have a walk to make them bounce to show they're real' ... Stephanie Fox has 32K boobs

article.caption: Model with 38KKK boobs is saved by airbags
I was terrified my PIP implants were a ticking timebomb. I just wanted them out
'I'm proud to be UK average size 16. And I'll never yo-yo again'
How to drive Men Mad

articles.articlebody:
STEPHANIE FOX has something she'd like to get off her chest... her back-breaking, all-natural, size 32K boobs are casting a shadow over her life.

The 21-year-old can't get a boyfriend, can't find clothes to fit and can't even walk down the street without getting an earful of abuse.

Men don't look her in the eye. Girls assume she is a porn star. Then there's the back pain.

She says: "Lots of women want big boobs but it's actually a total nightmare.

"The only men I attract are the sleazy type. It's rare that a guy looks me in the face when talking to me.

"Guys will flat-out stare and try all the cheesy chat-up lines. And a lot of the time they want their picture taken with them. Not me  them."

She adds: "Sometimes it can be a bit scary. A few blokes will try to get really hands-on. When I'm out with my male friends they'll usually circle round me. They're my bodyguards."

Stephanie doesn't fare much better with other girls. She says: "Women assume my boobs are fake  they look at me like I'm a porn star. It's older women who always comment on them.

"They'll tut and shake their heads as they walk past me in the street. I can hear them saying, 'They're so fake', and, 'Look at her flaunting them'.

"I try to smile through it. I know they're real but sometimes it can be hurtful.

"I've developed a way of walking so my boobs bounce up and down and people can see they're real. It looks like I'm walking on the moon.

"Women can get quite jealous  that's probably why I have more male friends."

But meeting the right guy is difficult. Glasgow girl Stephanie says: "I broke up with my ex in 2010. He couldn't handle all the attention I get and became insanely jealous.

"When we were out he'd get mad when other guys checked me out. I tried telling him it couldn't be helped  he knew what he was getting into."

Stephanie has seen a few men since the split but no one special has caught her eye.

She says: "They become too obsessed with my boobs, it's all they think about. It's hard to find a guy to see past them.

"A lot of blokes are just after me for the status of it, they see it as just another notch on the bedpost.

"I want my boyfriend to see me for me, I'm more than just a pair of boobs. I'm a laid back and a down-to-earth girl and I love to have a laugh." Stephanie's boobs proved something of an overnight sensation when she was just 12.

She recalls: "It was so weird. I was a total cheeseboard then one day I woke up with a C cup. It was really annoying because I loved PE and sport.

"I was really into hurdles and running but my boobs started to restrict me. And as I got bigger, it was harder to find a sports bra."

During one family holiday in America Stephanie and her mum Josie, 51, went in search of one that would fit.

She recalls: "We tried this lingerie shop to get a measurement. I was 19 and about a 30J at that point.

"The staff couldn't believe it. Instead of measuring me they just kept calling more and more staff members out of the back to stare at them."

Stephanie adds: "Finding a bikini is atrocious. Nothing fits me so I have to buy separates. "I'll buy a size 12 for my lower half and a 20 for my top half  but even that's too small and they'll be spilling out all over the place. I also get serious back pain.

"Exercise is a nightmare. To do any exercise I have to wear a bra then a sports bra on top.

"I'll go to my local gym and I just get stared at. Gym clothes are quite tight so the guys will full-on stare."

Stephanie doesn't know how she got her huge boobs  though there is something in her family genes.

She says: "My mum does have big boobs but she's probably more of a DD or an E. But my sister Morena has normal-sized breasts.

"Whenever I visit her she'll say, 'God, Stephanie, can you give me some of your boobs!'"

She adds: "I think my dad and older brothers found it awkward when I blossomed. They didn't like men checking me out on the beach. We went on holiday to Italy last year. We went to a water park and I was getting a lot of male attention. Wives were whacking their husbands over the head for staring."

Stephanie works in her parents' fancy dress shop, where she is able to stitch her clothes to fit. She says: "If I don't adjust tops they swamp me or I just look huge. So I've become quite the seamstress."

As for the future, Stephanie plans to start her own business and says: "I know it sounds weird but I'd love to run my own corn on the cob stall.

"I saw a stall selling sweetcorn when I was 15 and ever since, that's what I've wanted to do. You can have butter and pepper on it and things like that  it would be pretty cool."

And despite all the aggro she gets over her shape, on balance she wouldn't want to downsize.

She says: "A part of me loves the attention. They're a great talking point and I get to meet a lot of people. But the downsides probably outweigh that one positive.

"And even the attention can be a double-edged sword. Some days I just don't want to be stared at."

myView

By CAROL COOPER, Sun Doctor

ABNORMALLY large breasts can cause a number of problems, mostly due to the sheer weight. They change the way a woman stands, increasing the curvature of the spine and putting extra strain on it.

This makes back and neck pain common. It can be even worse if the woman has to lift anything heavy.

Shoulders can also suffer, with bra straps causing deep grooves from the weight they support. Nerve pain down the arm can occur, sometimes with tingling in the fingers.

Sweating under the breasts is inevitable, so dermatitis and infections are common, with ulceration in bad cases.

Exercise is tricky. Some women wear two bras at once but it is hard to stop breast discomfort.

Adverse comments can make the woman feel very ill at ease and some become stressed and even depressed.

a.jones@the-sun.co.uk
articles.teaser: STEPHANIE'S back-breaking, all-natural boobs are subject of daily abuse from strangers
articles.headline: My natural 32K boobs are a nightmare...only sleazy blokes chat me up while girls tut and assume I'm a porn star
articles.subdeck: 'I have a walk to make them bounce to show they're real' ... Stephanie Fox has 32K boobs

image.caption: Driven ... Karren Brady the glamorous businesswoman

article.caption: The Apprentice unveiled
Karren: I'm hired
Apprentice teens 'top the adults'

articles.articlebody:
APPRENTICE star and Sun columnist Karren Brady is the no-nonsense football boss who has become one of Lord Sugar's key TV advisers.

A workaholic, she became the UK's youngest managing director of a public limited company at 23, at Birmingham City FC. She is now vice-chairman at West Ham.

Karren has two kids with hubby, former player Paul Peschisolido.

Here, in extracts from her inspiring new book, Strong Woman: Ambition, Grit And A Great Pair Of Heels, Karren, 42, offers some hilarious anecdotes.

I HAVE a desire for independence, the need for control  or what others call sheer bloody-mindedness.

But recently I've had to dwell on why I became who I am. I don't reflect on such things easily because I've never been an emotional person. I'm logic personified.

Looking back over my life, I tried to work out how and where the desire for independence began to make itself felt.

Among my earliest memories was when I was three and my mum Rita and nan Nina left me at home one day with my grandfather, Gerald, while they went shopping.

I remember my mum and dad, Terry, had this elegant drinks cabinet in the lounge. As a toddler I was fascinated by it.

The door folded down and all these beautiful little glasses and different-coloured bottles glinted away in the backlight.

I decided to get a chair, climb up and have a good look. Everything looked even better close up.

The dainty little glasses (for sherry), the perfect size for me, were so tempting that I started to fill them with the green, yellow and clear liquids I saw in the bottles  crème de menthe, advocaat and vodka.

Taking little sips and inviting my dolls to do the same, I was having a wonderful time  until my grandfather came into the room and asked what I was doing.

Of course, as soon as he twigged, he told me to stop. Three-year-old me instantly replied: "This is my house and I'll do as I want."

He left me to it. He was married to my grandmother, so perhaps he knew not to pick a losing fight.

Not surprisingly, when my mum and nan got home I was rolling drunk and, by all accounts, not much more co-operative.

My grandfather got an earful, I was put to bed and the story passed into family lore.

As my nan used to tell me: "You were such a little cow  and you know what? You weren't sick, not once. Not a drop."

When you've got that streak in you as a toddler, no one's ever going to be able to tell you what to do when you're fully grown.

It wasn't a one-off, either.

A few months later my mum took me to school for the very first time.

Picking me up after my first day, she asked the teacher how I had got on. She had been worried, my mum admitted, because I was very shy.

"Which one is your daughter?" the teacher asked.

"Karren Brady," said my mother.

"Karren Brady?" was the incredulous response. "Shy? She walked in, pulled a boy off his chair and said, 'That's my seat. Move.' I wouldn't be worried if I was you!"

It was advice my mother took to heart. In fact, that was probably the last time she worried about me.

There were other powerful influences in my childhood.

Both of my grandmothers were hard workers, strong women and very important in moulding me.

I was very close to Nina, my mother's mother, in particular, who put an end to that alcoholic tea party when I was three. She was dynamite. She was Italian  from Naples  and incredibly feisty. She would have killed for her family  she wouldn't have thought twice about it.

If someone cut up my grandfather in traffic, she would get out of the car and punch them on the nose.

I'm sure it won't come as any surprise when I say she was definitely the one in control of her house and marriage.

She was great with money  not because she had a lot but because she knew the price of everything and she was in charge.

My grandfather went out to work as a postman but she would take his wages and give him cash to spend.

That was just the way it was. Grandma Nina really believed in me. Her attitude was: You can do it, so go out there and get on with it.

Even if I get a bit feisty at home now, my husband will still say to me, "Oh, Nina's here. Nina's coming out."

I was fiercely determined. If I wanted something and my parents wouldn't give it to me, I would find a way to get it for myself.

I was never given pocket money. My parents always offered to buy me what I wanted but I wanted to be in charge of my own money.

I recall them once saying no to something  I can't remember what it was  but I haven't forgotten what I decided to do. I put up signs in my bedroom window  it was my bedroom so I could do what I liked, I reasoned  saying, "Massages, manicures, come inside!"

My mother was shouting up: "Who are all these weirdos coming to the door?"

And I bawled back: "They're my customers."

I was bloody-minded too. I once put up a Vote Labour poster in my bedroom just because my parents were Conservatives.

My dad roared: "Take that down!"

I said: "It's my bedroom!"

He said: "What does the poster even mean?" And I didn't know, of course. I just knew it would wind him up and cause a debate.

When I was about 14, I'd tell my mum I was going to stay the night with my best friend, Charlotte, who would tell her mum she was staying at my house.

After that we would meet up with our clothes in carrier bags, get changed, take the Tube into central London then go out in Soho.

When everything closed we'd walk around until the Tube re-started in the early morning and go back to our borough  Enfield in north London.

Then we walked around until 10am before we went home.

Mum would say, "Well, you look very tired." But she never knew. Years later, when I told her, she was shocked. But I was even more shocked by what she said to me.

She looked at my daughter Sophie and said: "What goes around, comes around."

I went very cold and felt terrible about what I had done.

But at the time I couldn't have cared less.

Nothing was going to happen to me. I was in control, I was safe  or at least I thought I was.

But if I imagine my 15-year-old Sophie going out all night now, well...



The day I made a name for myself



MY school had lots of careers days and companies came in and talked to us, including advertising agency Saatchi & Saatchi and the London radio station LBC.

Lots of people were interested but whereas everybody thought maybe they'd write to them, I got all the right details before the people left.

The next day I was on the phone making appointments.

Both companies I was interested in offered me a job.

I chose Saatchi, leaving school on the Friday and starting work there the following Monday.

Though I was only 18, they put me on their graduate programme. I suppose they saw something in me.

Though I loved it, the programme was very rigid, so finally I got impatient and moved instead to LBC as a 19-year-old selling radio advertising.

I had been given Asian Hour to sell, which was pretty tough  a 4am to 5am slot, the real graveyard shift.

I had been handed a list of companies that spent money on advertising but who didn't advertise on radio. One was Sport Newspapers.

I got through to owner David Sullivan on the phone and he wasn't interested, saying "radio didn't work".

I decided I would drop off some material at his office  persistence is everything  and once I was there I decided to wait to meet him in person.

I waited and waited and waited and in the end he agreed to see me because I had waited so long.

I did a very quick pitch to him and he wasn't buying it at all, so I said: "Look, if you take the advertising and sales don't go up, you don't have to pay for it."

He said: "That sounds good to me."

I didn't have the authority to do a deal like that, so it was a risk  but I remember thinking, "Well, if it doesn't work out, what's the worst that can happen? They can fire me but I can always get another job. I'm only 19."

I still use that kind of thinking and I have done all my life.

In fact, it's the foundation of my confidence and my ability to take risks.

It worked out. Sales went up and, within months, Sullivan was spending more than £2million a year on radio advertising.

I was managing it all and earning more commission than all the other sales staff put together.

Then he offered me a job, which I accepted.

That episode is often considered to have been a turning point in my professional life but, in truth, I think my life had been heading that way since I was a young child.

Adapted by BEN JACKSON Strong Woman: Ambition, Grit And A Great Pair Of Heels, by Karren Brady, is published by HarperCollins on March 29, £18.99.
articles.teaser: FUNNY anecdotes from the Apprentice star and West Ham vice-chairman's new book
articles.headline: Brady: I told Grandad, I'll do what I like
articles.subdeck: Driven ... Karren Brady the glamorous businesswoman

image.caption: Kiss ... lizard George and Lizzie Griffiths show affection

article.caption: Bride's £3k for lizard
Holiday rep-tile
Mantis preys on luckless lizard

articles.articlebody:
BRIDE Lizzie Griffiths told last night why she spent her £3,000 wedding fund on saving her beloved pet lizard George from cancer.

Lizzie admitted: "Some people might think it's mad, but I'd do anything to make George better."

"I was more than willing to spend all the wedding cash on treatment for George  without the treatment he would have been put down."

Lizzie postponed her wedding to fiance Chris Fisher  and last month George became the first bearded dragon in the UK to have radiotherapy.

She said: "I wake up at 5.30am each day so we can have a cuddle because if I don't get much time with him it upsets me.

"He comes into our bed and snuggles under the duvet while I feed him chocolate worms."

The primary school teacher, 26, of Purley, South London, lost her heart to bearded dragon George at an animal rescue centre last year.

Lizzie said: "I took one look at him and fell completely in love. He was so handsome.

"When I first held him he burrowed into my neck. I was so attached I put his tank at the end of our bed."

Chris asked Lizzie to marry him last August. Lizzie had a bow tie designed for George to wear at the wedding.

But in October, she was horrified when she spotted a growth on his face and a vet told her it was cancer.

The couple decided to cancel their big day and spend the £3,000 they had saved on pioneering radiotherapy.

George is now in remission. Chris, 26, said he has accepted that George always comes first. He added: "I think their relationship is adorable."

j.tippett@the-sun.co.uk
articles.teaser: BRIDE tells why she spent her £3k wedding fund on saving beloved bearded dragon
articles.headline: I halted my wedding to save pet lizard George

image.caption: Flight of fancy ... Edward plants a smacker on Airwolf chopper

article.caption: I'm in love with 3ft statue of Adonis

articles.articlebody:
SOME people are accused of treating their partners "like objects"  and that charge is apt here.

The Sun told yesterday how 40-year-old carer Reighner Deleighnie is in a relationship with a 3ft statue of the Greek god of desire Adonis, who she calls Hans.

Reighner, of south London, is the latest in a small but growing group of "objectophiles" who believe their sexual orientation should not have a stigma attached.

The concept is not new. As far back as 1877 a statue of Venus de Milo was the subject of a court case when a gardener was caught trying to have sex with "her".

More recently, American Edward Smith has expressed his love for his VW Beetle, Vanilla, though he admits having "relationships" with many vehicles.

His most intense sexual experience was "making love" to a helicopter from the Eighties TV series Airwolf  but his major love is cars.

Edward said: "I go a little bit beyond appreciating the beauty of a car, to the point of what I feel is an expression of love.

"I write poetry about cars, I sing to them and talk to them like a girlfriend.

"I'm not sick. Cars are just my preference."

We told earlier this month how Leeds shop assistant Amanda Whittaker, 27, has fallen for the Statue of Liberty, or "Libby" as she knows her. At school she loved a drum kit.

In 1979, Eija-Riitta Eklöf from Sweden "married" the Berlin Wall. Eija, who changed her surname to Berliner-Mauer, coined the term Objectum Sexual (OS) for her unconventional orientation.

Mrs Berliner-Mauer says her "long-distance" relationship survived the "tragedy" of the wall being pulled down in 1989  but she has fallen for a red fence. Former US soldier Erika LaBrie, 41, pledged to love, honour and obey the Eiffel Tower in an intimate ceremony in Paris in 2007.

Erika Eiffel founded the Objectum Sexuality Internationale group which has more than 40 members and a website.

Other "inanimate lovers" revealed by objectophiles include a cartoon character, steam locomotives, words, public buildings and a hydraulic flood barrier.

San Francisco sexologist Dr Amy Marsh carried out a scientific survey involving 21 objectophiles and found cars, trains and aircraft are the most common objects of desire.

But more women than men are objectophiles and they are more likely to love structures.

Dr Marsh said: "OS transcends fetishism and is experienced as a sexual and/ or affectionate orientation with an array of emotions.

"It does not seem to be caused by trauma or delusional psychiatric conditions, though it does seem linked with autism.

"Professionals need to learn more about OS and treat OS patients with the same respect they do for other sexual preference minorities."

For more information go to dramymarshsexologist.com.

m.phillips@the-sun.co.uk
articles.byline: By MARTIN PHILLIPS, Senior Feature Writer
articles.teaser: MEET the 'objectophiles'  a growing number of people who are attracted to objects
articles.headline: The best sex of my life?

image.caption: Out soon ... Madonna's new album MDNA

article.caption: Madonna: I like to work with people who talk about philosophy or quantum physics

articles.articlebody:
MADONNA is back  bigger, brighter and bolder then ever  with her electrifying new album MDNA.

And you can listen for FREE with The Sun below.

The album will be released Monday, March 26 on Interscope, so this is your chance to hear it here first.

The Queen of Pop reclaims her crown with this her 12th studio album to date; a collection of shiny, dancefloor anthems set to take the roof off summer.

Co-written by Madonna, album highlights include the glorious William Orbit-produced I'm A Sinner, which recalls the heyday of Ray of Light, and Falling Free, a beautiful, soaring ballad.

There's a pounding clubland stomper in Turn Up The Radio, produced by French electronic DJ and producer Martin Solveig.

Then there's the poptastic punch of Superstar, featuring Madonna's daughter Lourdes on backing vocals, I Don't Give A featuring Nicki Minaj and first single Give Me All Your Luvin, feat. Nicki Minaj & M.I.A., which were both produced by Martin Solveig.

Renowned Italian electro house DJ and producer Marco "Benny" Benassi adds an extra sheen to salacious rave-ups I'm Addicted and Girl Gone Wild.

articles.headline: First listen of Madonna album
